definitions.definition: material that is made of string, thread or wire twisted or tied together, with small spaces in between; a piece of this material used for a particular purpose

examples.text: Unfortunately the animals are often caught in **fishing nets**.
She's always peering through the net curtains, spying on the neighbours.
They began to cut through the net, one strand at a time.
We slept in bamboo beds draped in mosquito nets.
The fishermen were mending their nets.
He bagged a huge net of carp and bream.

definitions.definition: the frame covered in net that forms the goal

examples.text: to kick the ball **into the back of the net**
She shot the ball past the goalkeeper and into an empty net.
Kane finally **found the net** in the 78th minute.

definitions.definition: the piece of net between the two players that the ball goes over

examples.text: She hit her second serve straight into the net.
to hit the ball over the net

definitions.definition: a piece of ground with a net around it, used for practising batting and bowling

examples.text: He practised bowling all morning in the nets.
He spends his time playing computer games and **surfing the net**.

definitions.definition: a network of radios or computers that are connected to each other

examples.text: A call on the radio net went out that there had been a crash.

definitions.definition: to consider a lot of different people, activities, possibilities, etc. when you are looking for something

examples.text: It’s worth casting your net wide when applying for your first job.

definitions.definition: when somebody/something slips through the net, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them

examples.text: We tried to contact all former students, but one or two slipped through the net.

definitions.definition: to consider a wide range of possibilities or cover a large area, especially to try to find somebody/something

examples.text: They have spread their net far and wide in the search for a new team coach.

definitions.definition: to consider or include a larger range of options or possibilities, especially when searching for something

examples.text: It's time to widen the net in the search for a suitable candidate.

wordOrigin: noun Old English net, nett, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch net and German Netz.
